title: 108_hr1039
content: The Act is titled the "Wholesale Motor Fuel Fairness and Competition Restoration Act." It includes findings related to the wholesale motor fuel industry. The Congress finds that various unfair and anticompetitive practices by oil companies contribute to unjustified retail motor fuel prices charged to American consumers. These practices include price zoning, redlining, discriminatory pricing, and a complex cost allocation system. Oil companies engage in unfair practices such as price zoning, redlining, and discriminatory wholesale pricing of motor fuel to manipulate prices and gain an unfair market advantage. Oil companies engage in discriminatory pricing practices, using complex cost allocations to hide factors and manipulate wholesale prices. This allows them to charge different prices to various types of retail stations in the same community, giving them an unfair market advantage. The Federal Government aims to prohibit unfair oil company practices in cost, pricing, and marketing to restore fair competition in the wholesale fuel market and empower consumers to understand price changes at the pump. The Federal Government aims to prohibit unfair oil company practices in cost, pricing, and marketing to restore fair competition in the wholesale fuel market and empower consumers to understand price changes at the pump. Price discrimination prohibition is emphasized in Section 3. The Act prohibits terminal facilities from selling motor fuel at a higher price to any person than what it charges others, with exceptions for pre-existing contracts. The Act prohibits differential pricing for motor fuel at terminal facilities, with exceptions for pre-existing contracts. The Federal Trade Commission can impose a civil penalty of up to $1,000,000 for violations, and criminal penalties include fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. This section will take effect 6 months after the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. FULL DISCLOSURE. The Federal Trade Commission, in consultation with the Secretary of Energy, will require refiners and distributors to fully disclose their wholesale motor fuel pricing policies, including all cost components. This includes crude oil costs, refining, marketing, transportation, equipment, overhead, profit, rebates, incentives, and market enhancement allowances. Regulations will also establish pricing procedures for terminal facilities owned or affiliated with distributors or retailers. The regulations will take effect 6 months after the enactment of this Act. The Federal Trade Commission will ensure public dissemination of information acquired under regulations issued regarding wholesale motor fuel pricing policies. Information will be made available through the Energy Information Administration and displayed at retail motor fuel facilities for consumer understanding. This requirement will take effect 6 months after the enactment of this Act. The requirements for public dissemination of wholesale motor fuel pricing information will not apply to trade secrets or protected commercial information under the Freedom of Information Act. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. Any term defined in section 101 of the Petroleum Marketing Practices Act shall have the same meaning in this Act.
